Yes, the 2014 Commonwealth Games had a significant political and social impact on Scotland, as the event was widely seen as a chance for the country to showcase its identity and unique culture to the world, and to boost its international profile in the run-up to a referendum on independence from the United Kingdom, which was held just a few weeks after the games.

From a political standpoint, the Scottish government saw the Commonwealth Games as an opportunity to demonstrate its ability to host a major international event and to promote Scotland as a global destination for sport, tourism, and business. The games were also a chance for the Scottish government to assert its cultural autonomy by incorporating Scottish music, arts, and traditions into the opening and closing ceremonies.

The 2014 Commonwealth Games also had a significant economic impact on Scotland, generating millions of pounds in revenue from ticket sales, tourism, and investment in infrastructure and facilities. The games were also credited with helping to stimulate Scotland's economy by creating new jobs and opportunities for local businesses.

On a social level, the Commonwealth Games were widely celebrated throughout Scotland, with thousands of people volunteering to help with the event and millions more tuning in to watch the games on television. The games helped to bring people from different backgrounds and communities together, fostering a sense of unity and pride in Scottish identity.

Overall, the 2014 Commonwealth Games had a profound impact on Scotland, both politically and socially, and helped to raise the country's profile both at home and abroad.
